repnme.cdata!:
Trinidad and Tobago - Postal Services
            Reform Program

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Trinidad and Tobago
            Postal Services Reform Project were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was high, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: privatization
            may be an unrealistic objective of postal service reform;
            privatization may be an unrealistic objective of postal
            service reform; service standards should be defined in a
            demand-driven manner; Postal sector transformation is a
            long-term process, and unlikely to be completed within the
            life of one project; Broad-based commitment of key
            stakeholders is a necessary precondition to successful
            reform; pioneering transactions should be more modest in
            setting key indicators, and allow for their adjustments in
            the course of implementation, and concentrate more on
            lessons learnt. Also, Lessons from world-wide experience and
            World Bank studies indicate that successful Management
            Contracts have the following characteristics: (1) Robust,
            meaningful and relevant performance indicators; (2) Emphasis
            on incentive fees and financial performance indicators; and
            (3) Operational autonomy by the operator.

repnme.cdata!:
Trinidad & Tobago - Postal Services
            Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Postal Services Reform Project seeks
            to expand the coverage and quality of postal services,
            achieve major efficiency gains, and, become more responsive
            to client needs. In addition, an increased private sector
            participation will be pursued, through performance-based
            management delegation and further long term involvement of
            the private sector. The components include: 1) improving
            labor efficiency, through a voluntary separation employment
            package, consistent with the country's labor laws, and
            granted after consultation with the union; 2) increasing
            private sector participation. This component includes the
            offer of a Delegated Management Arrangement (DMA) to a
            corporation or consortia as the first phase in the transfer
            of operation and management to the private sector; 3)
            modernizing facilities, through the rehabilitation,
            refurbishment and replacement of existing equipment and/or
            buildings. This component includes the upgrade of counter
            automation and information systems; 4) strengthening
            institutional capacity, through disbursement of funds for
            the capital investment program and performance monitoring.
            Deregulation of postal services and implementation of the
            second phase of private sector participation, offering a
            Long Term Arrangement (LTA) for a deeper private sector
            involvement, are included.
